Fields.DialogueText: How are things, Lieutenant?
As far as the ship is concerned, all seems to be going well, Captain.
The crew, however, is somewhat less stable.
Does this have anything to do with Hans Lody?
Yes, Captain. I understand she will be of great aid to us in the future. But her presence makes things a little more... complicated.
Hopefully she won't cause too many waves. Where is she, by the way?
She might be in her room, or scouring the ship for information.
I see. Have her report to me at once.
I'll see to it, Captain.
Ja? You called, Kapitän?
That was... quick.

Fields.MenuText: I need your input on some battle schematics here.
Have you found anything new on the Morganas?
I'm curious. How do you think the rest of the crew sees you?

Fields.DialogueText: So? Very well.
I have, and I'm currently working on how I might best exploit the information I have.
I don't think, Kapitän, I KNOW I make some uneasy.  That does not mean I care.
*ALARM*
Captain, we need you both on the bridge.
It seems we'll have to continue this conversation later, Hans. Let's go.
@BATTLE
That last battle was well fought, but we were lacking in certain areas of combat.
Though there were no casualties, we were sloppy in our ship maneuvers, and slower to fire than we ought to be.
I agree, Captain. Those Morganas were more agile than we expected.
What do you think, Hans?
The main cannons were not calibrated properly, for one.
My apologies, Hans, but I assure you that we calibrate those guns every morning.
Was soll das heißen? That I'm a bad shot?
Not at all. I'm merely stating the fact that we calibrate the guns with the utmost care.
Well, your standards obviously aren't up to par with mine!

Fields.MenuText: This briefing was meant to be constructive.

Fields.DialogueText: And my constructive criticism is that you ought to better calibrate my guns.
Lieutenant, why don't you leave us? Hans and I will continue this briefing without you.
Very well, Captain.
How dare he insinuate that I'm at fault!
You're not a bad shot, Hans, but from what I've seen, your temper does affect your performance somewhat.
Excuse me?!
*ALARM*
Again, we must postpone the conversation.
Na gut!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: There is no need for anyone to get upset over this.
We all want the same thing here.

Fields.DialogueText: What we want is not the issue. How we get it matters.
Will anything improve unless somebody complains?
What are you doing here in the mess hall, Oberleutnant? This is the fourth time you've been out here.
I couldn't sleep, so I thought I'd look over some items here.
Photos and a postcard. Who are they from?
My boyfriend.
Albert Vogel. A ship mechanic.
Y-yes, he is stationed on...
Stationed on the destroyer Friedrich Ihn.
How did you know?
Friedrich Ihn is one of my sisters. I make it my mission to know what goes on aboard her ship.
I see. Then you must have heard Albert was injured in combat.
Or so he tells you. I heard he was in a scuffle with another crew member over a woman.
What? What are you getting at?
It seems he hasn't been honest with you.
I-I have to go.
Hans? What did you say to Rita? She seemed upset.
Ich habe ihr die Wahrheit erzählt. That her boyfriend is a liar, and likely a cheater.

Fields.MenuText: And what benefit do we gain from telling her that?

Fields.DialogueText: She forgets about him and focuses on our mission.
Now! If you'll excuse me.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: How is she supposed to focus on her job if you break her heart?
Sometimes the truth hurts, but you did her a favor.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't want crew members wasting their time with useless distractions.
She was hardly focused on her job while she pined for an unsuitable lover. This solves the problem.
Whether she accepts the truth or not is her own problem.
You wanted to meet with me, Lieutenant?
Yes, Captain. I request permission to go aboard Friedrich Ihn.
I'm sorry, Rita, but we're mid-mission. You're needed here for the time being.
All right... why not this instead? Could we use another mechanic on board? Albert Vogel, aboard the Friedrich Ihn, is the best of the best.
We could always use another mechanic, but-
But we are not accepting him on board!
Hans, this really isn't any of your concern.
Nein? I am the ship, Kapitän! Besides, the likelihood of the Friedrich Ihn's Kapitän - not to mention Command - giving Vogel permission to come aboard is next to none.
Well, there's no reason I can't ask. Rita, I will check with the Friedrich Ihn's captain.
Thank you, thank you so much, Captain.
Why did you give into such a request?

Fields.MenuText: We do need a mechanic. And if such a move results in higher morale for one of my officers, I don't see why I shouldn't ask.

Fields.DialogueText: The relationship between Oberleutnant Cardy and that mechanic is only going to cause problems.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: If he's their best mechanic, they won't transfer him to us. We indulge Officer Rita, nothing happens with our request, and we move on.
I just want a mechanic. I'm not doing this for Officer Rita.

Fields.DialogueText: Ich hoffe Sie haben Recht. If he comes aboard, you know the situation with Oberleutnant Cardy will only get worse.
Then the right answer is to find another mechanic. Not him.
I'd like to return to an earlier topic of conversation, Hans.
Was denn?
Having you on board has been of great benefit to us, but there have been some concerns expressed by the crew.
What are they complaining about now?
There have been reports of you threatening crew members and getting involved in their personal issues by spreading rumors.
They're not rumors. I am merely relaying my findings to the appropriate individuals to help resolve issues.
Relaying these "findings" does not resolve issues, Hans.
A good leader must also offer solutions if their goal is to promote a healthier crew.
The crew is healthy! They're doing their jobs, aren't they?

Fields.MenuText: Doing their jobs doesn't mean they're happy. Our performance certainly hasn't improved.

Fields.DialogueText: Then they just need to work harder.

Fields.MenuText: They need more support from you and less criticism. A crew must operate like a well-oiled machine.

Fields.DialogueText: Now you're throwing platitudes at me?

Fields.MenuText: I'm just trying to explain things to you.

Fields.DialogueText: The only thing you're trying is my patience, Kapitän!
Don't worry, I'm sure you'll find a way to balance things out.
Do I look worried? Meeting adjourned, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Hello, Captain. Good to see you on the mess decks.
Chef Bruno, do you have a minute?
Certainly, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: You see Hans every day, right?
Do you know what kind of food Hans likes?
Did Hans stop by today?

Fields.DialogueText: Hans Lody? The Belle of the ship that won't stop pestering me or my staff?
Nothing with onions in it, that's for sure.
Judging by how calm the room is, I'd say no.
Goodness, is she really that much trouble?
She means well, but every line she utters always ends with a critique or harsh opinion.
Why, just the other day she started an argument with my staff which then turned into an altercation.
My, I do apologize for her behavior.
Don't worry about it, Captain. So, how may I help you?
I'd like you to prepare us some food.
Planning a romantic dinner?
Very funny. No, I'm just hoping to get on her good side.
Well, in that case, you can't go wrong with desserts.
Excellent! I'd like you to prepare some desserts for us. I know it's asking a lot, but I'll make it worth your while.
It will be my pleasure, Captain. In fact, desserts are my specialty.
Thank you, Chef. I'm looking forward to it.
@BATTLE
The one and only.
*ALARM*
Hello, Hans.
Was ist das?
I had the chef prepare some of your favorite desserts.
I realize I might have been a little too hard on you during our last talk, and this is my way of making it up to you.
In other words, this is your way of saying that I was right and you were wrong.
That's not exactly accurate... but sure, why not.
It's completely accurate.

Fields.MenuText: How about we start things off with some cheesecake?
So how about some marble cake?
Would you like tea before dessert?

Fields.DialogueText: Finally, something we see eye to eye on!
Only if I can have all of it.
Desserts come first, Kapitän. You should know that.
How did you know these were my favorite desserts?
Chef Bruno told me you were always pestering him to prepare them.
That sneak! My food choices are supposed to be confidential.
Just enjoy it, Hans. There's no need to overthink this.
Mmm... these are delicious!
Aren't they?
I suppose I should thank you for the gesture, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
I guess those desserts will have to wait.
Now those Morganas are asking for it! No one interrupts me during my dessert time!
@BATTLE
I'm glad you agreed to send our request to Friedrich Ihn's captain about transferring Albert Vogel over. Did he provide us with an answer?
Ja. He did.
What does the radio transmission say?
He has agreed to transfer him over. He's no use to the ship as a mechanic while he's recovering from a broken arm.

Fields.MenuText: Harsh but fair. We can still use him on board for something, I guess.

Fields.DialogueText: How is he able to work on the ship engines with a broken arm?
He can supervise the less-experienced mechanics.
If you say so. Friedrich Ihn's Kapitän has provided us with the exact coordinates and time for the transfer.
Great! Thank you, Hans.
... Of course, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: So much for hoping the transfer wouldn't actually happen.
Is he going to be any use to us with a broken arm?

Fields.DialogueText: That will teach you to be careful what you ask for! You might just get it.
Ha! Now you finally realize how flawed your plan truly was, eh?
What do you plan to do with him, exactly?
I didn't say that.
A shame we can't always enjoy the day when nice weather finally comes along. Got any plans, Hans?
Hmm...
Busy there? If I may, can I inquire what it is you're doing?
Writing, Kapitän.
Again? What, if I may I ask?
She's probably writing down the latest gossip from her recent escapade into the mess hall.
Do not flatter yourself, Lieutenant.
Gossip in my hands is information, and information is what I specialize in.
I take it you two have read the agenda today?
Yes, Captain. We have already prepped the sick bay to receive Albert Vogel.
I still can't believe Friedrich Ihn's Kapitän allowed you to transfer him over to us.

Fields.MenuText: He seemed rather relieved about it. Perhaps he needed the extra room for more injured personnel.

Fields.DialogueText: There's the transport ship.
All right, everyone - prepare to have that transport ship dock.
What is that trailing the transport ship?
Morganas! But how did they find us? This was supposed to be a secure transaction.
*ALARM*
Blast! All hands on deck and prepare for battle!
Yes, Captain!
Any idea what we're up against here, Hans?
Ich bin mir nicht sicher. The Morgana force doesn't seem different from others we've faced... but something doesn't quite feel right.
Don't worry. I'll get to the bottom of this in short order.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Maybe this plan wasn't a great idea...
Thanks. You've already made your position quite clear, Hans.

Fields.DialogueText: Not clear enough to prevent you from doing it.
That should be another clue. Their Kapitän is happy to get rid of him for a reason.
Too late to cancel now, Kapitän.
Quite a few wounded in sick bay, Captain. We're struggling to keep up.
Do the best you can with them. I know you'll take good care of them.
*ALARM*
We'll try...
@BATTLE
Is that all of them?
That should be it, Captain. All the injured crew are here.
Where's Hans? She was supposed to meet us here.
Last I saw her, she was up on the main deck by herself. I'll go look for her.
Please do.
We're at full capacity, but the sick bay should hold everyone for now. Let us hope there aren't more injuries in the future.
Nurse, is there anything else you would need? More supplies or equipment?
I'll manage, Captain. Fortunately we are well equipped and my assistant is highly trained.
By the way, where is Albert Vogel?
In the aft section. Rita's keeping an eye on him.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you. Please keep me informed of anything that may be cause for concern.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain.
You should get some rest now.
You're right. I'll check on him later.
Sounds like a plan.

Fields.MenuText: Does he look like a troublemaker to you?
How is he?

Fields.DialogueText: Pardon? I'm not sure what I'm supposed to say to that.
He took a hard shrapnel hit when the battle started. So far he hasn't spoken a word and appears to be in a deep sleep.
Captain, Nurse Emi has reported that someone's been going through sickbay. Someone who shouldn't be there.

Fields.MenuText: Quite the claim. Is she certain of this?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, she met with me this morning to inform me her medical files have been rummaged through.

Fields.MenuText: Do you know if anything is missing?
And she wasn't able to apprehend or identify the trespasser?

Fields.DialogueText: No files were missing. Fortunately, Nurse Emi stumbled upon the would-be culprit before anything was taken.
No, Captain. She is sure the trespasser was female, though, and saw the shady character run down towards the crew quarters.
Hm.
We might have a stowaway on board, Kapitän.
Do you have proof of this, Hans?
Nein. Not yet. But I assure you I will find out what is going on here.
Is there a plan of action we should take, Captain?
As of now, I want you to inform Nurse Emi that her files will be placed under guard while Hans and I find out what's going on here.
Yes, Captain.
*ALARM*
I'll rendezvous with you later, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Hello again, Kapitän.  As I was saying before those enemies interrupted me-
*ALARM*
Scheiße!  It's as if the Morganas are trying to throw me off the trail of our troublemaker on board!
Wouldn't surprise me... Let's make sure they fail.
@BATTLE
You saw us through, Hans. Good work out there.
As if my work can be anything else.
Ever the consummate braggart, right?
You know it!
You seem to be in a good mood. Would you care to share why?
On top of my victory in battle, I've also made progress on our stowaway problem.

Fields.MenuText: Please elaborate.
Who is it?
Then we must root out these individuals at once.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid I can't explain here, for fear someone might be listening.
It's been brought to my attention that we are dealing with more than one person.
I will have a plan drawn up straightaway to do just that.
Very well. I want to discuss your findings and lay out a plan to apprehend these traitors at once.
Ja, Kapitän.
Do you have any idea how long he will be in this state, Nurse?
I wish I could say, but it could be some time before he shows progress. He did sustain a significant injury during the personnel transfer when the Morganas attacked.
Are you sure everything is being done to keep him well?
I know you're worried, but I can assure you I am doing all I can to help him. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to check on other patients.
How is your boyfriend, Oberleutnant Cardy? Still sleeping?
What do you want, Hans? I really don't have time for your games.
Games? Why, I'm just as concerned as you are.
Concerned? I doubt it. So what other rumors have you heard about my Albert to add insult to injury?
Since you asked, I'll tell you. I know for certain he was seeing another woman while he was on Friedrich Ihn.
You have no proof!
Nein. I do - and I can produce witnesses when required.
Just leave me alone, will you?!
What's with all the commotion here? Why is Lieutenant Cardy running off?
She and I were just having a talk, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Do your talks always end with her being upset?

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes. I take joy in tugging at her sensitive strings.
*ALARM*
Meet with me after this battle.
Ja, Kapitän.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Spoken with a sly grin. You really are something.
Morganas are the enemy, not our own crew. Try to remember that.

Fields.DialogueText: I tend to grin after every victory, Kapitän.
We also have people on board, not Morganas, working against us. Try to remember that, Kapitän.
Come in, Hans. Have a seat.
So, what is this "important matter" you needed to speak to me about?

Fields.MenuText: Does the name Admiral Stein ring a bell?
How do you feel about a visit from the admiral?
Are you good at making speeches?

Fields.DialogueText: It does ring a bell.
If security measures are adhered to at the highest level, then I have no objections.
As if you didn't know the answer. I'm exemplary at speeches!
Is there something going on?
The newly appointed German deputy liaison to the Neutrality fleet, Admiral Stein, will soon be visiting our ship.
I see.
So above everything else that's been happening, you're now tasked with handling his visit. Are we clear?
Crystal clear, Kapitän.
Meeting adjourned, then.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Captain, I need to speak with you at once!
What is it?
During your war meeting, the guard assigned to those medical records was attacked - nothing lethal, but I'll bet his ears will be ringing for days.
Oh, fantastic. Do you have any idea who it was? Does Hans know about this?
Oh, Hans knows. She caught our intruder, but she wouldn't tell me who she caught.
So that's why she left the meeting early. Very well, Lieutenant. Please cover for me at the bridge while I go see Hans.
Yes, Captain.
A Few Minutes Later...
Good work, Hans. Can you identify her?
Follow me, and I'll show you. We both know who she is.
Cardy? I'd love to hear an explanation, Lieutenant.
I am sorry, Captain, but I have my reasons.
She was searching for Albert Vogel's medical files.
To what end?
To cross-reference her notes with a particular note in his medical file. Doing so allows her to decode a message.
A message?

Fields.MenuText: This has the stench of espionage all over it.
Care to explain yourself, Cardy?
I suggest that you tell me precisely the message you decoded, including its sender.

Fields.DialogueText: I just can't, Captain.
I must decline.
If you explain yourself and cooperate, your sentence may be less harsh in the end.
I can't.
Sehr gut. I have all the information I need to carry out my investigation.
Very well. Hans, escort her to the forepeak. We will continue accordingly later.
*ALARM*
Ja, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
No answer?
I always knew there was something off about you.
You are too polite, Kapitän. This is not a time for charm. This is a time for credible threats.
The files seem to have been accessed.
Tell me everything you know about Lieutenant Cardy.
She and Albert Vogel are agents of the Republic of China. Cardy's a proper spy - "Rita Cardy" is a false identity through and through - and Vogel was... suggestible.
They were sent to our fleet to spy on Axis ships and send information on their specifications back to China.
How long have you suspected Rita of being a spy?
Since the first time I saw her. She was always up early before everyone else and was always going through notes and photos.
What tipped you off?
There were short poems in her postcards. Bad French, mostly gibberish - full of mistakes, as though they were teaching themselves the language from dictionaries and broad linguistic parallels.
To the casual observer it was... charming and awkward. As it was meant to be. But I soon discovered that there was a coding system embedded within it.

Fields.MenuText: So, long story short, she had us all for fools. Especially me. Had I not allowed Albert to be transferred over, maybe this wouldn't have happened.

Fields.DialogueText: On the contrary, Kapitän. Having Albert transferred over was the only way I was able to decipher the codes.
Because half of the coding was in his files?
You catch on quickly, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
We will discuss this further following the battle.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Clever. Admirable, in a way.
Taking advantage of our situation with Morganas - and for what? Money?

Fields.DialogueText: I can admire skill, even in my enemies, but these two disgust me, Kapitän.
Their betrayal deserves only one reward. Paying with their lives, Kapitän.
For having exposed two spies on board, you still seem very tense, Captain.
Something still isn't right, Lieutenant.
How so?
We never discovered who the stowaway was.
Maybe there wasn't one. I think it was Cardy the whole time.
Something isn't adding up.

Fields.MenuText: Have you noticed how the Morgana attacks have increased?
The Morganas' efforts are more concerted now than ever before.
I get the feeling our security is still compromised.

Fields.DialogueText: Now that you mention it, I have.
You're right. They employed wave-like tactics in the beginning, but now they're setting up elaborate coordinated attacks.
Really, why?
What do you suggest we do?
We wait.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Because the Morganas are attacking more frequently. They seem to anticipate our actions.
Captain, I suppose your idea of waiting worked. Assuming your plan was to get attacked again...
That wasn't quite what I was thinking.
*ALARM*
I didn't mean to sound...
@BATTLE
Hallo, Kapitän. Come to enjoy a meal with me?
I'm sorry, I didn't realize you were eating. Do you mind if I join you?
Not as long as you don't touch my chocolate cake.
These battles are getting worse by the day.
Nein! You know my rules about eating. No business talk during meal time.
Very well.

Fields.MenuText: So what passions do you have outside of work?
Have you tried baking before?
Who does your hair? I like it.

Fields.DialogueText: I love to travel and read.
I've tried it a few times. Chef Bruno even offered to teach me. But I prefer to just eat. That's the fun part.
That's the first time you've complimented me on my physical qualities! It's about time.
See? Was a little bit of normal conversation so hard?
You need to relax, Kapitän. If a firebrand such as myself can learn to loosen up, then so can you.
You're right. I think I'll head off and do something fun.
I wouldn't call writing incident reports fun, but suit yourself.
I wasn't going to do that. Oh... you were being sarcastic.
Ja. I was.
That must be why you can speak so many languages.
Forget it, Lieutenant. Just get ready to fight.
Why did you call me here, Hans?
Oberleutnant Cardy has something she wants to tell you.
Is that so? What is it?
You mentioned before that... if I helped you in any way, you would lessen my punishment. Is that right?
Don't push your luck.
A lesser punishment is on the table. Why don't you start by telling me who you are? Is anything in your file - Hong Kong upbringing, English banker father, all that - true?
Oh, most of that's rubbish. I was born in Shanghai, though I did spend some time in Hong Kong. My name's Larissa Chen. My father was Chinese, my mother Russian.

Fields.MenuText: Very well. How are you planning on helping us?
Can I trust you?
I don't care if you say your real name is Rumpelstiltskin. You have a lot of work to do if you want us to believe you.

Fields.DialogueText: I can tell you where I've hidden all the information I've gathered.
By admitting to you I'm a spy, I've already signed my death warrant. I have nothing else to gain by lying, unless...
Yes, I suppose I must disclose everything.
*ALARM*
We will discuss the terms after this. In the meantime, come up with a plan that will convince me to help you.
@BATTLE
It's going to take something good to save your neck.
You can still call me Rita, though. I've gotten used to it.
So are you ready to help us?
Yes, Captain. I will direct you to where you can find my stash of information.
Thank you, Rita. Turning over this information might help your case.
As for Albert, though... well, I'm not sure what Command will do with him, once he wakes up.
I never wanted him to become a spy. I knew that only bad things would come of it.

Fields.MenuText: Then why become one yourself?
Are you sure you want to go through with this?
Maybe somebody on high will take that into account... if he knows something we value.

Fields.DialogueText: It was the only way to be with him.
Yes, I'm sure.
It's a nice thought, isn't it?
Very well, then. I will set up a meeting with Hans to decide what to do.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Do you have a moment, Edwards?
It would seem so.
I have some concerns about all of this fog we've seen lately.
As do I, Captain. I would even dare to say-
*ALARM*
It would seem I was wrong to think we'd have a moment to talk...
@BATTLE
This fog seems to be growing thicker by the day, Edwards.
I believe it's following us, Captain. Nearby ships have reported no fog for weeks.

Fields.MenuText: It sounds preposterous.

Fields.DialogueText: Everything is preposterous, as far as the Morganas are concerned.
True.
Do you have a plan, Captain? What should we do?
We have to make preparations at once. I'm not sure what the Morganas are planning, but I'm confident they're planning something.
Relay my concerns to Hans Lody. Her insight will prove valuable.
Yes, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I don't believe in coincidence.
What the heck are we going to do about it?

Fields.DialogueText: Me neither. Morganas are craftier than some people give them credit for.
I was hoping you might know.
What have you found out, Hans?
I discovered something remarkable while decoding a piece of writing in Albert's notes to Rita. It reveals the location of the stowaway.
Where? Where is the stowaway?
Inside Albert Vogel himself.
What?!
Do you know how crazy that sounds?
Rita, do you remember when I said Albert was injured in a skirmish involving a woman? Well, it seems my information was only partially correct.
A woman forced him to attack the Friedrich Ihn's Kapitän, but a crewmember stopped him before he could succeed.
I don't understand.
He is being controlled by a Morgana. Corruption, more than likely. She brainwashed him, likely during a battle, and has been using him ever since.
To what end?
To take control of Friedrich Ihn's Kapitän. She would then use his position to take control of other high ranking members of the fleet. Yourself included, Kapitän.
Me? Then why hasn't Vogel attempted to attack me?
Because his coma put him - and his Morgana puppetmaster - out of commission. Consider yourself lucky, Kapitän.
So... what happens to my Albert now?
As soon as he wakes up, the Morgana will no doubt attempt to continue her work.
How do we stop her?
Es ist offensichtlich. We must defeat Corruption in battle.
*ALARM*
In that case, following this battle, we must make finding that ship our top priority. Understand?
Ja, Kapitän.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: How original...
Defeating Morganas? That's our specialty.
I had the same idea.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed!
Glad we think alike, Kapitän!
Don't tell me you had a better plan. You didn't.
Where is Hans? We have Corruption in our sights.
I don't know, Captain.
Where could she be?
Finally.
Hans, I've been looking everywhere for you. There's the ship. Do you have any tactical advice?
Keep as much distance between us and Corruption as possible. I'm sure she'd jump at the chance to brainwash more members of our crew.

Fields.MenuText: Well, then, are you ready to give her what for?
Feeling scared?
Let's do this!

Fields.DialogueText: I'm always ready, Kapitän.
You're joking, aren't you? Fear isn't in my vocabulary.
Now you're talking!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Relax. Ich bin da.
Thank you for doing your part to save Albert, Captain.
It's my job, Miss Chen. Just make sure you hold up your end.
*ALARM*
As I was saying...
@BATTLE
A nasty battle. They never give up, do they?
Neither do we, Kapitän.
Your plan worked, Hans. Albert is waking up, and it appears as if Corruption has left him. I owe you a great debt of gratitude.
Are you sure Corruption didn't brainwash anyone else on board, Hans?
I'm confident, Kapitän. I know what to look for now.
So, what next?
I believe we have a party to prepare for. Admiral Stein should be visiting in a few days.
Ah, hell. I completely forgot about that. In that case...
Everyone, back to work!

Fields.MenuText: Why would I want your gratitude?
You did your best to make things right, I suppose.
That won't make up for the fact that you're a spy who infiltrated the crew, recruited your lover to be a spy, and conspired against us.

Fields.DialogueText: I... I will have to live with what I've done.
That might be easier than you think. You may not live much longer at all, traitor.
Good one, Kapitän!
You must be kidding, Kapitän! At best, she deserves a fast death instead of a slow one.
(gulp)
But I will keep watching, you can be sure.
Feels like we've been out at sea for months. Judging by how quickly we're moving toward the shore, you must be missing land, too.
I do love the view of beaches.
There's one particular beach, near my hometown, that I am especially fond of.
Maybe now that things have settled down somewhat, you can take some time off and return to that beach.
Hmm. Vielleicht eines Tages. Someday.

Fields.MenuText: You're acting oddly calm, Hans. It's a nice change.
Care for a stroll on the sand sometime?

Fields.DialogueText: Keep talking like that and this calm will end as soon as it began.
I'd love to.
Another group of Morganas, Hans. Get your guns ready!
They are always ready, Kapitän - and I have personally verified their calibration.
@BATTLE
